description: From Middle English furre, forre, from Anglo-Norman forre, fuerre (‚Äúa case; sheath‚Äù), from Frankish *f≈çdar, from Proto-West Germanic *f≈çdr, from Proto-Germanic *f≈çdrƒÖ (‚Äúsheath‚Äù) (compare Old English f≈çdor (‚Äúsheaf‚Äù), Dutch voering (‚Äúlining‚Äù), German Futter (‚Äúlining‚Äù), Gothic êçÜêçâêå≥êçÇ (f≈çdr, ‚Äúsheath‚Äù)), from Proto-Indo-European *peh‚ÇÇ-, *poh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúto protect‚Äù) (compare Lithuanian piemu≈ç (‚Äúprotection‚Äù), Ancient Greek œÄ·ø∂œÖ (p√¥u, ‚Äúflock‚Äù), œÄ·ø∂ŒºŒ± (p√¥ma, ‚Äúlid‚Äù), œÄŒøŒπŒºŒÆŒΩ (poim·∏ón, ‚Äúshepherd‚Äù), Old Armenian ’∞’°÷Ç÷Ä’°’∂ (hawran, ‚Äúherd, flock‚Äù), Northern Kurdish pawan (‚Äúto watch over‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø (pƒÅti, ‚Äúhe watches, protects‚Äù).
The verb is from Middle English furren, from Anglo-Norman furrer, forrer, fourrer (‚Äúto line, stuff, fill‚Äù), from the noun.

entries.meaning: The hairy coat of various mammal species, especially when fine, soft and thick.
The hairy skin of an animal processed into clothing for humans.
A pelt used to make, trim or line clothing apparel.

definitionGroups.group: A coating, lining resembling fur in function and/or appearance.

entries.meaning: The soft, downy covering on the skin of a peach.
The deposit formed on the interior of boilers and other vessels by hard water.
The layer of epithelial debris on a tongue.
(heraldry) One of several patterns or diapers used as tinctures.
(hunting, uncountable) Rabbits and hares, as opposed to partridges and pheasants (called feathers).
A furry; a member of the furry subculture.

verbs.description: fur (third-person singular simple present furs, present participle furring, simple past and past participle furred)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover with fur or a fur-like coating.
(intransitive) To become covered with fur or a fur-like coating.
(transitive, construction) To level a surface by applying furring to it.
